cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
What name is given to the soft spots on a baby's head which, during birth, enable the bony plates of the skull to flex allowing the child's head to pass through the birth canal?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
During childbirth, a baby's head may need to change shape slightly to fit through the birth canal. The soft spots on a baby's head, known as fontanelles, are areas where the bony plates of the skull have not yet fused together. These fontanelles allow for flexibility and compression of the skull during delivery. There are typically two main fontanelles: the anterior fontanelle, located at the top of the head, and the posterior fontanelle, located at the back of the head. 

Answer: Fontanelles

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
What name is given to the soft spots on a baby's head which, during birth, enable the bony plates of the skull to flex allowing the child's head to pass through the birth canal?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Humans are born with a very malleable fetal head which is not fully developed when the infant exits the womb. This soft spot on the crown of the infant allows for the head to be compressed in order to better fit through the birth canal without obstructing it. This allows for the head to develop more after birth and for the cranium to continue growing without affecting the birthing process.\n', 'As the fetus develops, the facial bones usually form into pairs and then fuse together. As the cranium fuses, sutures are formed that resemble stitching between bone plates. In a newborn, the junction of the parietal bones with the frontal and occipital bones, form the anterior (front) and posterior (back) fontanelle, or soft spots. The separation of the cranial bone plates at time of birth facilitate passage of the head of the fetus through the mother\'s birth canal, or pelvic girdle. The parietal bones, and occipital bone can overlap each other in the birth canal, and form the unusual looking "cone head" appearance in a newborn when delivered in a natural, or vaginal, delivery.\n', 'The deletion of this combination of genes results in several distinctive congenital features, occasional defects in the heart, kidneys, and urinary tract. The disorder is associated with an enlarged parietal foramina which can cause openings in the two bones that form the top and sides of the skull. These abnormal openings form extra "soft spots" on the head, in addition to the two that newborns normally have, and unlike the usual newborn soft spots, the enlarged parietal foramina remain open throughout life. Other signs can include multiple mostly noncancerous benign bone tumours called osteochondromas (exostosis), developmental delay, vision disorders and craniofacial abnormalities. It is classified as a rare disease.\n', "The baby's skull has seven bones. Normally, these bones don't fuse until around age 2, giving the baby's brain time to grow. Joints called cranial sutures, made of strong, fibrous tissue, hold these bones together. In the front of the baby's skull, the sutures intersect in the large soft spot (fontanel) on the top of the baby's head. Normally, the sutures remain flexible until the bones fuse. The signs of craniosynostosis may not be noticeable at birth, but they become apparent during the first few months of the baby's life. The symptoms differs from types of synostosis. First of all there is Sagittal synostosis (scaphocephaly). Premature fusion of the suture at the top of the head (sagittal suture) forces the head to grow long and narrow, rather than wide. Scaphocephaly is the most common type of craniosynostosis. The other one is called Coronal synostosis (anterior plagiocephaly). Premature fusion of a coronal suture — one of the structures that run from each ear to the sagittal suture on top of the head — may force the baby's forehead to flatten on the affected side. It may also raise the eye socket and cause a deviated nose and slanted skull. The Bicoronal synostosis (brachycephaly). When both of the coronal sutures fuse prematurely, the baby may have a flat, elevated forehead and brow.\n", 'These joints are synarthroses. It is normal for many of the bones of the skull to remain unfused at birth. The fusion of the skull\'s bones at birth is known as craniosynostosis. The term "fontanelle" is used to describe the resulting "soft spots". The relative positions of the bones continue to change during the life of the adult (though less rapidly), which can provide useful information in forensics and archaeology. In old age, cranial sutures may ossify (turn to bone) completely.\n', 'A fontanelle (or fontanel) (colloquially, soft spot) is an anatomical feature of the infant human skull comprising any of the soft membranous gaps (sutures) between the cranial bones that make up the calvaria of a fetus or an infant. Fontanelles allow for rapid stretching and deformation of the neurocranium as the brain expands faster than the surrounding bone can grow. Premature complete ossification of the sutures is called craniosynostosis.\n', 'A fontanelle is a soft spot in the skull of a baby where the bones of the skull have not yet knit together, but normally will do so in time.\n', "Brachycephaly, or a 'short head', is the result of a closure of both the coronal sutures. Following Virchow's law, this will result in a child's head with a restriction of growth in the forward direction and in the backward direction: recessed frontal bones and a flattened occiput. Compensatory growth will occur sideways, due to the sagittal suture, and upwards, due to the lambdoid sutures.\n", 'Craniosynostosis is a condition in which one or more of the fibrous sutures in an infant skull prematurely fuses, and changes the growth pattern of the skull. Because the skull cannot expand perpendicular to the fused suture, it grows more in the parallel direction. Sometimes the resulting growth pattern provides the necessary space for the growing brain, but results in an abnormal head shape and abnormal facial features. In cases in which the compensation does not effectively provide enough space for the growing brain, craniosynostosis results in increased intracranial pressure leading possibly to visual impairment, sleeping impairment, eating difficulties, or an impairment of mental development.\n', 'Craniosynostosis is a condition in which one or more of the fibrous sutures in an infant (very young) skull prematurely fuses by turning into bone (ossification), thereby changing the growth pattern of the skull. Because the skull cannot expand perpendicular to the fused suture, it compensates by growing more in the direction parallel to the closed sutures. Sometimes the resulting growth pattern provides the necessary space for the growing brain, but results in an abnormal head shape and abnormal facial features. In cases in which the compensation does not effectively provide enough space for the growing brain, craniosynostosis results in increased intracranial pressure leading possibly to visual impairment, sleeping impairment, eating difficulties, or an impairment of mental development combined with a significant reduction in IQ.\n']

Task Description:

which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To address the question regarding the soft spots on a baby's head that facilitate childbirth, we can extract and analyze several key concepts from the provided passages. The relevant content includes:

1. **Fontanelle (or Fontanel)**: This term is explicitly defined in the passages as the anatomical feature of an infant's skull that refers to the soft spots where the cranial bones have not yet fused. This is crucial for understanding the question, as the term "fontanelle" is the scientific name for the soft spots in question.

2. **Cranial Sutures**: The passages describe cranial sutures as the joints made of fibrous tissue that hold the bones of the skull together. Understanding these sutures is important because they are the points where the skull bones meet and where the fontanelles are located. The flexibility of these sutures allows for the necessary compression of the skull during birth.

3. **Malleable Fetal Head**: The passages mention that humans are born with a malleable fetal head, which is not fully developed. This malleability is essential for the baby's head to compress and fit through the birth canal, highlighting the functional role of the fontanelles during delivery.

4. **Development After Birth**: The passages indicate that the soft spots allow for further brain growth and skull development after birth. This is significant because it emphasizes the importance of the fontanelles not only during delivery but also for the infant's growth and development in the early months of life.

5. **Craniosynostosis**: This condition is mentioned in the passages as a situation where one or more of the sutures in an infant's skull prematurely fuses. Understanding craniosynostosis is relevant because it contrasts with the normal development of fontanelles, illustrating the potential complications that can arise if the skull bones fuse too early.

6. **Cone Head Appearance**: The passages describe how the overlapping of cranial bones during delivery can lead to a temporary "cone head" appearance in newborns. This phenomenon is a direct result of the flexibility provided by the fontanelles and sutures, which is important for understanding the physical changes that can occur during birth.

### Analysis of the Role of These Contents:

- **Terminology and Definitions**: The definitions of "fontanelle" and "cranial sutures" provide the necessary vocabulary to accurately discuss the anatomical features involved in childbirth. This enhances clarity in communication about infant anatomy.

- **Functional Understanding**: The explanation of the malleability of the fetal head and the role of fontanelles in allowing for compression during birth helps to contextualize why these features are evolutionarily advantageous. This understanding is critical for comprehending the physiological processes involved in childbirth.

- **Developmental Context**: The information about post-birth development underscores the importance of fontanelles beyond the birthing process, indicating their role in accommodating rapid brain growth in infants. This highlights the dynamic nature of infant development.

- **Contrast with Abnormal Conditions**: The mention of craniosynostosis serves to illustrate the normal versus abnormal development of the skull, providing a broader perspective on the significance of fontanelles in healthy infant growth.

In summary, the extracted content enriches the model's understanding of the anatomical and physiological aspects of infant skull development and the significance of fontanelles during childbirth and beyond. This knowledge is essential for accurately answering the question posed.

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To answer the question about the soft spots on a baby's head that facilitate childbirth, we can build upon the initial reasoning by integrating additional relevant knowledge from the retrieved passages.

1. **Definition of Fontanelles**: The soft spots on a baby's head are referred to as fontanelles. These are gaps between the cranial bones that have not yet fused, allowing for flexibility during birth. The anterior fontanelle is located at the top of the head, while the posterior fontanelle is at the back. This anatomical feature is crucial for accommodating the shape changes necessary for the baby's head to pass through the birth canal.

2. **Role of Cranial Sutures**: The cranial sutures are fibrous joints that connect the bones of the skull. They remain flexible in infants, which is essential for the skull's ability to compress during delivery. This flexibility is what allows the fontanelles to function effectively during childbirth.

3. **Malleability of the Fetal Head**: The fetal head is not fully developed at birth, which contributes to its malleability. This characteristic is vital for the baby's head to adapt and fit through the narrow birth canal, minimizing the risk of injury during delivery.

4. **Post-Birth Development**: Fontanelles are not only important during childbirth but also play a significant role in the infant's growth after birth. They allow for the rapid expansion of the brain, which grows faster than the surrounding skull can accommodate. This underscores the importance of fontanelles in supporting healthy brain development in the early months of life.

5. **Craniosynostosis**: Understanding craniosynostosis, a condition where one or more sutures fuse prematurely, highlights the importance of fontanelles. If the sutures close too early, it can lead to abnormal head shapes and potentially restrict brain growth, illustrating the critical role that fontanelles play in normal skull development.

6. **Temporary Cone Head Appearance**: The overlapping of cranial bones during delivery can create a temporary "cone head" appearance in newborns. This phenomenon is a direct result of the flexibility provided by the fontanelles and sutures, demonstrating how these features facilitate the birthing process.

By synthesizing these points, we can see that fontanelles are essential not only for the birthing process but also for the ongoing development of the infant's skull and brain. They represent a remarkable adaptation that allows for both the safe passage through the birth canal and the necessary growth of the brain in early life.

### Answer:
Fontanelles

The question asks for the name given to the soft spots on a baby's head that allow for the flexibility of the skull during birth. The relevant passages provide a wealth of information about the anatomy of an infant's skull, the role of these soft spots, and their significance during the birthing process.

1. **Definition and Function**: The soft spots referred to in the question are known as "fontanelles" (or "fontanelle"). These are the membranous gaps between the cranial bones of an infant's skull. They serve a crucial function by allowing the skull to be flexible, enabling the bony plates to compress and overlap as the baby passes through the birth canal. This flexibility is essential for facilitating a safe delivery and accommodating the rapid growth of the brain after birth.

2. **Anatomical Context**: The passages describe how the skull of a newborn consists of several bones that do not fully fuse at birth. This lack of fusion is important as it allows for the necessary deformation of the skull during delivery. The anterior (front) and posterior (back) fontanelles are specifically mentioned as the primary soft spots that contribute to this process.

3. **Developmental Significance**: After birth, the fontanelles allow for continued brain growth, as the skull bones gradually fuse over time, typically completing this process by around age 2. The flexibility provided by the fontanelles is crucial for accommodating the rapid expansion of the brain during the early years of life.

4. **Clinical Relevance**: The passages also touch on conditions such as craniosynostosis, where the premature fusion of cranial sutures can lead to abnormal head shapes and potential complications. This highlights the importance of the fontanelles in normal skull development and the potential issues that can arise when this process is disrupted.

5. **Terminology and Usage**: The term "fontanelle" is used interchangeably with "soft spot" in colloquial language, emphasizing its anatomical and functional significance in both medical and everyday contexts.

In summary, the soft spots on a baby's head that facilitate the birthing process are called "fontanelles." They are critical for allowing the skull to flex during delivery and for accommodating brain growth in the early stages of life. Understanding the role of fontanelles provides insight into both normal developmental processes and potential medical conditions related to cranial development.

**Context-enhanced reasoning process:**

The question seeks to identify the name of the soft spots on a baby's head that facilitate the flexibility of the skull during childbirth. The analysis of the provided passages reveals several key insights about these anatomical features, known as fontanelles.

1. **Definition and Function**: Fontanelles are the soft, membranous gaps between the cranial bones of an infant's skull. They play a critical role during childbirth by allowing the skull to compress and change shape, which is essential for the baby's head to navigate through the birth canal. This flexibility is vital not only for a safe delivery but also for accommodating the rapid growth of the brain that occurs after birth.

2. **Anatomical Context**: The passages highlight that a newborn's skull is composed of several bones that remain unfused at birth. This anatomical arrangement is crucial for the deformation of the skull during delivery. Specifically, the anterior fontanelle (located at the top of the head) and the posterior fontanelle (located at the back) are the primary soft spots that facilitate this process.

3. **Developmental Significance**: After birth, the fontanelles allow for continued brain growth, as the skull bones gradually fuse over time, typically completing this process by around age 2. The presence of fontanelles is essential for accommodating the rapid expansion of the brain during the early years of life, which is a critical period for cognitive development.

4. **Clinical Relevance**: The passages also mention conditions like craniosynostosis, where the premature fusion of cranial sutures can lead to abnormal head shapes and potential complications. This underscores the importance of fontanelles in normal skull development and highlights the potential issues that can arise when this process is disrupted.

5. **Terminology and Usage**: The term "fontanelle" is often used interchangeably with "soft spot" in both medical and everyday contexts, emphasizing its significance in understanding infant anatomy and development.

In conclusion, the soft spots on a baby's head that enable the skull to flex during birth are called "fontanelles." They are essential for both the birthing process and the subsequent growth of the brain, providing flexibility and accommodating the rapid changes that occur in an infant's early life. Understanding the role of fontanelles enhances our comprehension of normal developmental processes and potential medical conditions related to cranial development.

**Answer:** Fontanelles

In the front of the baby's skull, the sutures intersect in the large soft spot (fontanel) on the top of the baby's head. Normally, the sutures remain flexible until the bones fuse. The signs of craniosynostosis may not be noticeable at birth, but they become apparent during the first few months of the baby's life. The symptoms differs from types of synostosis. First of all there is Sagittal synostosis (scaphocephaly). Premature fusion of the suture at the top of the head (sagittal suture) forces the head to grow long and narrow, rather than wide. Scaphocephaly is the most common type of craniosynostosis. The other one is called Coronal synostosis (anterior plagiocephaly). Premature fusion of a coronal suture — one of the structures that run from each ear to the sagittal suture on top of the head — may force the baby's forehead to flatten on the affected side. It may also raise the eye socket and cause a deviated nose and slanted skull. The Bicoronal synostosis (brachycephaly). When both of the coronal sutures fuse prematurely, the baby may have a flat, elevated forehead and brow.
", 'These joints are synarthroses. It is normal for many of the bones of the skull to remain unfused at birth. The fusion of the skull's bones at birth is known as craniosynostosis. The term "fontanelle" is used to describe the resulting "soft spots". The relative positions of the bones continue to change during the life of the adult (though less rapidly), which can provide useful information in forensics and archaeology. In old age, cranial sutures may ossify (turn to bone) completely.
', 'A fontanelle (or fontanel) (colloquially, soft spot) is an anatomical feature of the infant human skull comprising any of the soft membranous gaps (sutures) between the cranial bones that make up the calvaria of a fetus or an infant. Fontanelles allow for rapid stretching and deformation of the neurocranium as the brain expands faster than the surrounding bone can grow. Premature complete ossification of the sutures is called craniosynostosis.
', 'A fontanelle is a soft spot in the skull of a baby where the bones of the skull have not yet knit together, but normally will do so in time.
', "Brachycephaly, or a 'short head', is the result of a closure of both the coronal sutures. Following Virchow's law, this will result in a child's head with a restriction of growth in the forward direction and in the backward direction: recessed frontal bones and a flattened occiput. Compensatory growth will occur sideways, due to the sagittal suture, and upwards, due to the lambdoid sutures.
", 'Craniosynostosis is a condition in which one or more of the fibrous sutures in an infant skull prematurely fuses, and changes the growth pattern of the skull. Because the skull cannot expand perpendicular to the fused suture, it grows more in the parallel direction. Sometimes the resulting growth pattern provides the necessary space for the growing brain, but results in an abnormal head shape and abnormal facial features. In cases in which the compensation does not effectively provide enough space for the growing brain, craniosynostosis results in increased intracranial pressure leading possibly to visual impairment, sleeping impairment, eating difficulties, or an impairment of mental development.
', 'Craniosynostosis is a condition in which one or more of the fibrous sutures in an infant (very young) skull prematurely fuses by turning into bone (ossification), thereby changing the growth pattern of the skull. Because the skull cannot expand perpendicular to the fused suture, it compensates by growing more in the direction parallel to the closed sutures. Sometimes the resulting growth pattern provides the necessary space for the growing brain, but results in an abnormal head shape and abnormal facial features. In cases in which the compensation does not effectively provide enough space for the growing brain, craniosynostosis results in increased intracranial pressure leading possibly to visual impairment, sleeping impairment, eating difficulties, or an impairment of mental development combined with a significant reduction in IQ.
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate key information from the provided passages regarding the soft spots on a baby's head, known as fontanelles. Here’s a summary of the relevant information:

### Consolidated Information:
1. **Definition of Fontanelles**: Fontanelles, or soft spots, are the membranous gaps between the cranial bones of an infant's skull. They allow for flexibility during birth and accommodate the rapid growth of the brain after birth.

2. **Function During Birth**: The soft spots enable the bony plates of the skull to flex, facilitating the passage of the infant's head through the birth canal. This flexibility is crucial for a successful vaginal delivery.

3. **Developmental Aspect**: As the infant grows, the fontanelles gradually close as the cranial bones fuse together, typically completing this process by around age 2. This allows the skull to expand and accommodate brain growth.

4. **Craniosynostosis**: This condition occurs when one or more sutures in the skull fuse prematurely, affecting the normal growth pattern of the skull and potentially leading to increased intracranial pressure and other developmental issues.

5. **Anatomical Changes**: The junctions of the cranial bones form sutures, which are fibrous joints that remain flexible in infants. The ability of these sutures to remain unfused at birth is essential for both the birthing process and the subsequent growth of the brain.

### Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Understanding Relationships**: The information highlights the causal relationship between the presence of fontanelles and the ability of an infant to be born through the birth canal. This understanding can help the model infer that certain anatomical features are adaptations to specific biological challenges.

2. **Developmental Processes**: By learning how fontanelles contribute to skull growth and brain development, the model can better understand the implications of developmental conditions like craniosynostosis. This enhances its ability to reason about the consequences of anatomical changes over time.

3. **Dynamic Systems**: The model can infer that biological systems are dynamic and that changes in one aspect (e.g., premature fusion of sutures) can lead to a cascade of effects (e.g., abnormal head shape, increased intracranial pressure). This understanding is crucial for reasoning about complex biological interactions.

4. **Predictive Capabilities**: With knowledge of how fontanelles function and their role in development, the model can make predictions about potential health issues in infants with abnormal suture fusion patterns, thereby improving its predictive reasoning.

5. **Integration of Concepts**: The model can integrate concepts from anatomy, physiology, and developmental biology, allowing for more comprehensive reasoning about health, growth, and the implications of anatomical variations.

By consolidating this information, the model can enhance its ability to reason about biological processes, understand causal relationships, and make logical inferences based on anatomical and developmental principles. This will contribute to a more nuanced understanding of human biology and health-related issues.

question:
What name is given to the soft spots on a baby's head which, during birth, enable the bony plates of the skull to flex allowing the child's head to pass through the birth canal?
answer:
Reasoning process: 
During childbirth, a baby's head may need to change shape slightly to fit through the birth canal. The soft spots on a baby's head, known as fontanelles, are areas where the bony plates of the skull have not yet fused together. These fontanelles allow for flexibility and compression of the skull during delivery. There are typically two main fontanelles: the anterior fontanelle, located at the top of the head, and the posterior fontanelle, located at the back of the head. 

Answer: Fontanelles

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:
During childbirth, a baby's head must adapt to fit through the birth canal. The soft spots on a baby's head, known as fontanelles, are areas where the bony plates of the skull have not yet fused together. These fontanelles provide the necessary flexibility and compression of the skull during delivery, allowing the head to change shape slightly. 

There are typically two main fontanelles: the anterior fontanelle, located at the top of the head, and the posterior fontanelle, located at the back of the head. The presence of these soft spots is crucial not only for the birthing process but also for accommodating the rapid growth of the brain after birth. As the infant grows, the fontanelles gradually close as the cranial bones fuse together, usually completing this process by around age 2. 

Additionally, if the sutures of the skull fuse prematurely—a condition known as craniosynostosis—it can disrupt normal skull growth and lead to complications such as increased intracranial pressure. This highlights the importance of fontanelles in maintaining the dynamic nature of the skull during early development.

Understanding the role of fontanelles enhances the model's causal reasoning by illustrating the relationship between anatomical features and their functional significance during childbirth and brain development. It also allows for predictions about potential health issues related to abnormal suture fusion patterns, thereby improving the model's predictive reasoning capabilities. Furthermore, integrating concepts from anatomy, physiology, and developmental biology enables a more comprehensive understanding of human biology and health-related issues.

### Answer:
Fontanelles

Answer:

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

During childbirth, a baby's head may need to change shape slightly to fit through the birth canal. The soft spots on a baby's head, known as fontanelles, are areas where the bony plates of the skull have not yet fused together. These fontanelles allow for flexibility and compression of the skull during delivery, which is crucial for a safe passage through the birth canal.

There are typically two main fontanelles: the anterior fontanelle, located at the top of the head, and the posterior fontanelle, located at the back of the head. These fontanelles are not just simple gaps; they are critical for accommodating the rapid growth of the brain during infancy. The bones of the skull do not fully fuse until around age 2, which allows for this necessary brain development.

Additionally, the presence of fontanelles plays a significant role in preventing conditions such as craniosynostosis, where one or more sutures in the skull prematurely fuse. This condition can lead to abnormal head shapes and increased intracranial pressure, which may result in developmental issues. Understanding the function and importance of fontanelles can help in recognizing potential health concerns in infants.

By incorporating this comprehensive understanding of fontanelles, including their anatomical significance, developmental role, and implications for health, the model can provide more accurate and nuanced information regarding this topic.

**Answer: Fontanelles**

question_info.question: What name is given to the soft spots on a baby's head which, during birth, enable the bony plates of the skull to flex allowing the child's head to pass through the birth canal?
passages:
Humans are born with a very malleable fetal head which is not fully developed when the infant exits the womb. This soft spot on the crown of the infant allows for the head to be compressed in order to better fit through the birth canal without obstructing it. This allows for the head to develop more after birth and for the cranium to continue growing without affecting the birthing process.
As the fetus develops, the facial bones usually form into pairs and then fuse together. As the cranium fuses, sutures are formed that resemble stitching between bone plates. In a newborn, the junction of the parietal bones with the frontal and occipital bones, form the anterior (front) and posterior (back) fontanelle, or soft spots. The separation of the cranial bone plates at time of birth facilitate passage of the head of the fetus through the mother's birth canal, or pelvic girdle. The parietal bones, and occipital bone can overlap each other in the birth canal, and form the unusual looking "cone head" appearance in a newborn when delivered in a natural, or vaginal, delivery.
The deletion of this combination of genes results in several distinctive congenital features, occasional defects in the heart, kidneys, and urinary tract. The disorder is associated with an enlarged parietal foramina which can cause openings in the two bones that form the top and sides of the skull. These abnormal openings form extra "soft spots" on the head, in addition to the two that newborns normally have, and unlike the usual newborn soft spots, the enlarged parietal foramina remain open throughout life. Other signs can include multiple mostly noncancerous benign bone tumours called osteochondromas (exostosis), developmental delay, vision disorders and craniofacial abnormalities. It is classified as a rare disease.
The baby's skull has seven bones. Normally, these bones don't fuse until around age 2, giving the baby's brain time to grow. Joints called cranial sutures, made of strong, fibrous tissue, hold these bones together. In the front of the baby's skull, the sutures intersect in the large soft spot (fontanel) on the top of the baby's head. Normally, the sutures remain flexible until the bones fuse. The signs of craniosynostosis may not be noticeable at birth, but they become apparent during the first few months of the baby's life. The symptoms differs from types of synostosis. First of all there is Sagittal synostosis (scaphocephaly). Premature fusion of the suture at the top of the head (sagittal suture) forces the head to grow long and narrow, rather than wide. Scaphocephaly is the most common type of craniosynostosis. The other one is called Coronal synostosis (anterior plagiocephaly). Premature fusion of a coronal suture — one of the structures that run from each ear to the sagittal suture on top of the head — may force the baby's forehead to flatten on the affected side. It may also raise the eye socket and cause a deviated nose and slanted skull. The Bicoronal synostosis (brachycephaly). When both of the coronal sutures fuse prematurely, the baby may have a flat, elevated forehead and brow.
These joints are synarthroses. It is normal for many of the bones of the skull to remain unfused at birth. The fusion of the skull's bones at birth is known as craniosynostosis. The term "fontanelle" is used to describe the resulting "soft spots". The relative positions of the bones continue to change during the life of the adult (though less rapidly), which can provide useful information in forensics and archaeology. In old age, cranial sutures may ossify (turn to bone) completely.
A fontanelle (or fontanel) (colloquially, soft spot) is an anatomical feature of the infant human skull comprising any of the soft membranous gaps (sutures) between the cranial bones that make up the calvaria of a fetus or an infant. Fontanelles allow for rapid stretching and deformation of the neurocranium as the brain expands faster than the surrounding bone can grow. Premature complete ossification of the sutures is called craniosynostosis.
A fontanelle is a soft spot in the skull of a baby where the bones of the skull have not yet knit together, but normally will do so in time.
Brachycephaly, or a 'short head', is the result of a closure of both the coronal sutures. Following Virchow's law, this will result in a child's head with a restriction of growth in the forward direction and in the backward direction: recessed frontal bones and a flattened occiput. Compensatory growth will occur sideways, due to the sagittal suture, and upwards, due to the lambdoid sutures.
Craniosynostosis is a condition in which one or more of the fibrous sutures in an infant skull prematurely fuses, and changes the growth pattern of the skull. Because the skull cannot expand perpendicular to the fused suture, it grows more in the parallel direction. Sometimes the resulting growth pattern provides the necessary space for the growing brain, but results in an abnormal head shape and abnormal facial features. In cases in which the compensation does not effectively provide enough space for the growing brain, craniosynostosis results in increased intracranial pressure leading possibly to visual impairment, sleeping impairment, eating difficulties, or an impairment of mental development.
Craniosynostosis is a condition in which one or more of the fibrous sutures in an infant (very young) skull prematurely fuses by turning into bone (ossification), thereby changing the growth pattern of the skull. Because the skull cannot expand perpendicular to the fused suture, it compensates by growing more in the direction parallel to the closed sutures. Sometimes the resulting growth pattern provides the necessary space for the growing brain, but results in an abnormal head shape and abnormal facial features. In cases in which the compensation does not effectively provide enough space for the growing brain, craniosynostosis results in increased intracranial pressure leading possibly to visual impairment, sleeping impairment, eating difficulties, or an impairment of mental development combined with a significant reduction in IQ.
